label: 採物
本: A Tale of Flowering Fortunes:  Annals of Japanese Aristocratic Life in the Heian Period (Volumes One and Two) . Stanford University Press . 1980
説明文: Lit. things taken."  So called from the auspicious objects successively flourished by the Director (a sakaki branch, a staff, a sword, etc.), the torimono were probably intended as invitations to the god to grace the occasion with his presence.  Two songs accompnaied the elevation of each object, the first sung by  the First Chorus (motokata) and the next by the Second Chorus (suekata).  The torimono section ended with a dance by the Director, after which there was an intermission, with wine and dramatic sketches (pp. 410-11). [神楽、榊、本方、末方]"
